channel.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
channel.description:
Just looking for some feedback. A while ago, I made a post on MITB about writing a custom kernel for the PSP (school assignment). But, my teacher didn't give the class enough information to get anywhere close. As it turns out, he just wanted to see how far we could get, so there wasn't really a "score".
However, I'm still interested in creating a custom kernel for the PSP. However due to it being my only one, I was wondering if it would be a safer (and more applicable?) to create a "modchip" instead of flashing the NAND. There are a few reasons as to why I would prefer to do this:
[ol][li]By flashing the NAND, I would be erasing all of Sony's code (including the bootloader). So if I mess something up even once, I'm left with a fancy looking paperweight.[/li] [li]Since the kernel would be stored on a separate modchip (probably an EEPROM), I can easily reprogram it to my needs. Whether it be to add a new feature, or to fix runtime errors.[/li] [li]It would not only give me experience working with electronics, it would also help me become a better programmer. It would most likely be written in C/++, probably with some ASM if needed.[/li] [li]I just think it would be a fun thing to do[/li][/ol]
So if anyone here has any experience/resources with something like this, I would very much appreciate any help you can give.

item.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Muroth:

benheck forums have a very nice modding environment, a ton of very experienced people on there, benheck forums is kind of like, modding consoles to portables and what not, it has handhelds too.

Or dashhacks, they have been merging several of their forums together into dashhacks, it used to be psp-hacks.com, ps3-hacks.com etc.

Read full topic
item.source: Creating a Modchip for my PSP

item.source: Creating a Modchip for my PSP

item.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:11, topic:393542”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=490712.msg3589470#msg3589470 date=1304473230]

Yes, I’ve been using CFW since… 3.5 I believe? I have not created any homebrew apps, but I don’t believe I will have to because, as I understand it, when the IPL would load up my kernel, all the code would be my own, so I don’t have to worry about using sony’s code.

Then, the other issue would be, would this be a replacement kernel for PSP users to use, or just something for you to use. Also note, the PSP’s shell has barely any room to add lights, let alone a whole new chip. This might require taking out your UMD drive.

Well at first it would be for me to use. But then I would start a proper development thread somewhere, and people could use it as they wished. Or I could sell it like a normal xbox modchip or something.

And I know there’s not a whole lot of room. Especially since the Slims+ require that the unit be completely assembled before it will work. Not sure if there’s a pressure sensor, or I’ve just had bad wiring, but when I turned it on while it was disassembled, the light would turn on, but the MS light wouldn’t and the screen wouldn’t turn on.

Sounds like a loose connection somewhere, ive had my disassembled and was able to turn it on. Did you try plugging it in? (Myn was at the time cause I didn’t have a pencil o repair my batter back from Pandora mode).

Also, this would mean writing ISO support directly into the kernel, along with a popsloader of some sorts built-in if you wanted to sell modchips at all. Those are the main 2 features everybody looks for when look at CFW or HEN (LCFW).

Yes, I’m aware of having to write support for ISOs, and just about everything else. I understand that I’m going to have to write support for everything myself. This includes a UI framework, memory management, Memory Stick, UMD, ISO, NIC, etc.

I’m having second thoughts on using a modchip. It may be easier just to use the Time machine to load my IPL, and the rest of the kernel after that, but I can’t remember if the sony code is loaded before/after the IPL is.

Sony code is loaded after the IPL (6.20 or earlier, Sony caught the exploit before we noticed it), via the reason 6.20FW managed to have a pre-IPL permanent patch.
[/quote]

Awesome, so technically since I’m using the Prometheus 5.50 I should still be able to load all my code from my IPL right?

However, if I were to update to the latest OFW, would that remove my ability to load my custom kernel? Or would I have to patch the OFW files. I’d prefer to chip/CFW to work on any type of PSP. I’m curious if I were to use a chip, if I could hold a button (like Right Trigger/Shoulder/Bumper) and then interrupt the Sony IPL loading process physically.[/quote]
The closest you will get is 6.20 as this is the only firmware with a known perma-patch via pre-IPL. Newer firmwares have a check for this, and wont startup if they detect an error. I would suggest using the TM exploit on your custom Kernel first to make sure it would even startup. This would make it so you wont need a pandora as often is you screwed up. the NOTHING option in the TM can let you boot from the NAND if nothing is pressed.

Read full topic
item.source: Creating a Modchip for my PSP

item.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:10, topic:393542”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=490712.msg3589257#msg3589257 date=1304458231]

Yes, I’ve been using CFW since… 3.5 I believe? I have not created any homebrew apps, but I don’t believe I will have to because, as I understand it, when the IPL would load up my kernel, all the code would be my own, so I don’t have to worry about using sony’s code.

Then, the other issue would be, would this be a replacement kernel for PSP users to use, or just something for you to use. Also note, the PSP’s shell has barely any room to add lights, let alone a whole new chip. This might require taking out your UMD drive.

Well at first it would be for me to use. But then I would start a proper development thread somewhere, and people could use it as they wished. Or I could sell it like a normal xbox modchip or something.

And I know there’s not a whole lot of room. Especially since the Slims+ require that the unit be completely assembled before it will work. Not sure if there’s a pressure sensor, or I’ve just had bad wiring, but when I turned it on while it was disassembled, the light would turn on, but the MS light wouldn’t and the screen wouldn’t turn on.

Sounds like a loose connection somewhere, ive had my disassembled and was able to turn it on. Did you try plugging it in? (Myn was at the time cause I didn’t have a pencil o repair my batter back from Pandora mode).

Also, this would mean writing ISO support directly into the kernel, along with a popsloader of some sorts built-in if you wanted to sell modchips at all. Those are the main 2 features everybody looks for when look at CFW or HEN (LCFW).

Yes, I’m aware of having to write support for ISOs, and just about everything else. I understand that I’m going to have to write support for everything myself. This includes a UI framework, memory management, Memory Stick, UMD, ISO, NIC, etc.

I’m having second thoughts on using a modchip. It may be easier just to use the Time machine to load my IPL, and the rest of the kernel after that, but I can’t remember if the sony code is loaded before/after the IPL is.
[/quote]
Sony code is loaded after the IPL (6.20 or earlier, Sony caught the exploit before we noticed it), via the reason 6.20FW managed to have a pre-IPL permanent patch.[/quote]

Awesome, so technically since I’m using the Prometheus 5.50 I should still be able to load all my code from my IPL right?

However, if I were to update to the latest OFW, would that remove my ability to load my custom kernel? Or would I have to patch the OFW files. I’d prefer to chip/CFW to work on any type of PSP. I’m curious if I were to use a chip, if I could hold a button (like Right Trigger/Shoulder/Bumper) and then interrupt the Sony IPL loading process physically.

Read full topic

Yes, I’ve been using CFW since… 3.5 I believe? I have not created any homebrew apps, but I don’t believe I will have to because, as I understand it, when the IPL would load up my kernel, all the code would be my own, so I don’t have to worry about using sony’s code.

Then, the other issue would be, would this be a replacement kernel for PSP users to use, or just something for you to use. Also note, the PSP’s shell has barely any room to add lights, let alone a whole new chip. This might require taking out your UMD drive.

item.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:7, topic:393542”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=490712.msg3588809#msg3588809 date=1304397191]

Yes, I’ve been using CFW since… 3.5 I believe? I have not created any homebrew apps, but I don’t believe I will have to because, as I understand it, when the IPL would load up my kernel, all the code would be my own, so I don’t have to worry about using sony’s code.

Then, the other issue would be, would this be a replacement kernel for PSP users to use, or just something for you to use. Also note, the PSP’s shell has barely any room to add lights, let alone a whole new chip. This might require taking out your UMD drive.
[/quote]

Well at first it would be for me to use. But then I would start a proper development thread somewhere, and people could use it as they wished. Or I could sell it like a normal xbox modchip or something.

And I know there’s not a whole lot of room. Especially since the Slims+ require that the unit be completely assembled before it will work. Not sure if there’s a pressure sensor, or I’ve just had bad wiring, but when I turned it on while it was disassembled, the light would turn on, but the MS light wouldn’t and the screen wouldn’t turn on.[/quote]
Sounds like a loose connection somewhere, ive had my disassembled and was able to turn it on. Did you try plugging it in? (Myn was at the time cause I didn’t have a pencil o repair my batter back from Pandora mode).

Also, this would mean writing ISO support directly into the kernel, along with a popsloader of some sorts built-in if you wanted to sell modchips at all. Those are the main 2 features everybody looks for when look at CFW or HEN (LCFW).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:6, topic:393542”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=490712.msg3588772#msg3588772 date=1304395196]
Yes, I’ve been using CFW since… 3.5 I believe? I have not created any homebrew apps, but I don’t believe I will have to because, as I understand it, when the IPL would load up my kernel, all the code would be my own, so I don’t have to worry about using sony’s code.
[/quote]
Then, the other issue would be, would this be a replacement kernel for PSP users to use, or just something for you to use. Also note, the PSP’s shell has barely any room to add lights, let alone a whole new chip. This might require taking out your UMD drive.[/quote]

Well at first it would be for me to use. But then I would start a proper development thread somewhere, and people could use it as they wished. Or I could sell it like a normal xbox modchip or something.

And I know there’s not a whole lot of room. Especially since the Slims+ require that the unit be completely assembled before it will work. Not sure if there’s a pressure sensor, or I’ve just had bad wiring, but when I turned it on while it was disassembled, the light would turn on, but the MS light wouldn’t and the screen wouldn’t turn on.

item.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

zyle1992:

By flashing the NAND, I would be erasing all of Sony’s code (including the bootloader). So if I mess something up even once, I’m left with a fancy looking paperweight.

Not true at all. The all PSP1000’s and some 2000’s [all 3000’s and Go’s cannot be hacked with a full CFW, but there is a perma patch for 6.20OFW with a HEN that can brick those [not always], and require sending into sony at that point) with the correct motherboards can be un-bricked via a Pandora battery [puts psp into Sony service mode] and Magic Memory Stick (A memory stick that just has the Time Machine exploit [unbrick method used by Sony on these motherboards] to simply re-install CFW or OFW. I used the Time Machine exploit to actually hack my PSP back when I got it 2 years ago.

There is a tool called PSPIdent that can identify all of the information on a PSP. More information on that here:
http://www.psp-hacks.com/file/1725

If you need any help on information PSP related, please feel free to ask me on MSN:
kenshin1388@hotmail.com

I have been lingering around the hacking scene for a while now, and can right about tell you hacking methods for each version, and the best way to patch a CFW to work for all games. (5.50D3 with Prometheus-4 patch is what I use, and can play ‘3rd Birthday’ which requires 6.37). Just a tip though, writing your own kernel would mean writing your own firmware from scratch to go with it, as then all normal PSP functions would be crippled because of the changed kernel methods/names to do everything. (I know your not changing, but writing your own, but thats the same point)

Read full topic
item.source: Creating a Modchip for my PSP

item.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Muroth, post:2, topic:393542”]Are you talking about a permanent solder mod chip installed or just a removable mod chip? I have mod chips on my PS1 and PS2, but I haven’t made a custom kernel before. I’ve made my own homebrew apps, but nothing further.

Buy a cheap PSP on craigslist or something, they sell for around $20-50, if you want.

Good luck though I would love this to be a project. :)[/quote]

Yeah, I’m trying to make something like “Undiluted Platinum”. I can use/test my kernel because I have MIPS emulator.

Read full topic
item.source: Creating a Modchip for my PSP

@Muroth wrote:

Are you talking about a permanent solder mod chip installed or just a removable mod chip? I have mod chips on my PS1 and PS2, but I haven’t made a custom kernel before. I’ve made my own homebrew apps, but nothing further.

Buy a cheap PSP on craigslist or something, they sell for around $20-50, if you want.

Good luck though I would love this to be a project.

item.title: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Just looking for some feedback. A while ago, I made a post on MITB about writing a custom kernel for the PSP (school assignment). But, my teacher didn’t give the class enough information to get anywhere close. As it turns out, he just wanted to see how far we could get, so there wasn’t really a “score”.

However, I’m still interested in creating a custom kernel for the PSP. However due to it being my only one, I was wondering if it would be a safer (and more applicable?) to create a “modchip” instead of flashing the NAND. There are a few reasons as to why I would prefer to do this:

[ol][li]By flashing the NAND, I would be erasing all of Sony’s code (including the bootloader). So if I mess something up even once, I’m left with a fancy looking paperweight.[/li]
[li]Since the kernel would be stored on a separate modchip (probably an EEPROM), I can easily reprogram it to my needs. Whether it be to add a new feature, or to fix runtime errors.[/li]
[li]It would not only give me experience working with electronics, it would also help me become a better programmer. It would most likely be written in C/++, probably with some ASM if needed.[/li]
[li]I just think it would be a fun thing to do[/li][/ol]

So if anyone here has any experience/resources with something like this, I would very much appreciate any help you can give.

Read full topic
item.source: Creating a Modchip for my PSP
